content.question:
Labeled nucleotides were supplied to a cell culture before the cells began <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> replication. A simplified representation of the process for a short segment of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in Figure 1. Labeled <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></math> bases are indicated with an asterisk (*).

Figure 1. A simplified representation of the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> replication process

Which of the following best helps explain how the process represented in Figure 1 produces <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules that are hybrids of the original and the newly synthesized strands?

choices.label: Each template strand is broken down into nucleotides, which are then used to synthesize both strands of a new <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule.

Each template strand is broken into multiple fragments, which are randomly assembled into two different <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules.

Each newly synthesized strand is associated with another newly synthesized strand to form a new <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule.

Each newly synthesized strand remains associated with its template strand to form two copies of the original <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule.

content.answer: Each newly synthesized strand remains associated with its template strand to form two copies of the original <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule.
